values.alignmentText: Microsoft stack appears in finance and government, though Java and web frameworks dominate.
West coast cities see winter PM2.5 spikes, yet regulations are gradually improving air quality.
High religious pluralism and a sizeable non-religious population foster tolerance for atheists.
Vibrant democracy and active civil society keep autocratic drift low despite pressure from China.
Modern banks, ubiquitous ATMs, and contactless systems like EasyCard make transactions easy.
Accessible beaches line the east and south coasts, though they are more weekend escape than daily life.
Board game cafes and local publishers sustain an active tabletop scene in Taipei.
Subsidies and new public centers help but many families still rely on private care or relatives.
Cities feature playgrounds, safe transit, and family-friendly night markets.
Citizens receive monthly subsidies and expanding public preschool options.
Foreign residents can access subsidies after registration but English services are limited.
Hiking, night-market snacking, and gaming align well with the family's interests.
Friendly locals and organized expat groups create welcoming communities despite language gaps.
Visa renewals and business filings require Chinese paperwork, adding moderate bureaucratic friction.
Housing is pricey in Taipei, but food and transit remain affordable compared to U.S. cities.
Naturalization typically demands renouncing prior citizenship with narrow exceptions.
An export-driven tech economy maintains steady growth and low unemployment.
Capitalist market complemented by strategic state guidance and strong SMEs.
Public schools rank well internationally but emphasize rote learning and long hours.
Tech firms sponsor work permits, though openings often favor Mandarin speakers.
Mountains and parks offer greenery, yet industrial zones reduce overall environmental quality.
Progressive income tax around 5–20% plus NHI premiums keeps overall burden moderate.
Autumn days sit near 22–28°C (72–82°F) as typhoon season winds down, making it comfortable.
Family is culturally central, though long work hours can limit shared time.
Spousal and dependent visas are commonly approved, enabling the whole family to stay together.
Parental leave up to six months and child allowances support citizen parents.
Standard households receive basic tax deductions and education subsidies.
Foreign families access NHI and schools but miss some cash benefits.
Urban women blend East Asian streetwear with modest business attire.
Men favor casual street fashion alongside smart office wear.
Traditional expectations persist but younger generations show more gender flexibility.
A small yet growing sector hosts events like the Taipei Game Developers Forum.
Legal gender change is possible, though understanding outside Taipei remains limited.
Same-sex marriage and anti-discrimination laws put Taiwan ahead of most of Asia.
Work-centric culture still expects mothers to manage childcare, though attitudes slowly shift.
ARC applications are straightforward but rely on Mandarin documentation and local sponsors.
Rising seas and stronger typhoons threaten coastal and low-lying areas.
National Health Insurance delivers broad coverage with low out-of-pocket costs.
Foreigners join NHI after six months, accessing the same clinics at modest fees.
Universities are plentiful and affordable though highly competitive.
International programs exist, but most instruction remains in Mandarin.
Urban housing is compact and expensive, making family-sized units harder to afford.
Annual filing can be done online but is largely in Mandarin, often requiring an agent.
High enrollment and quality public schools with strong STEM focus.
Foreign children may attend public schools, yet language support varies by district.
Major cities host large Pride events and social acceptance is relatively high.
Mandarin dominates and outside tourist areas English proficiency can be limited.
Public opinion favors liberal democracy, and Marxist ideas are rare.
Men face moderate expectations to be breadwinners, though metro fashion softens stereotypes.
Tech, gaming, and language-exchange groups flourish in Taipei.
Monthly minimum wage near NT$27k (~USD900) signals baseline labor protections.
High-speed rail, 5G coverage, and smart-city projects indicate advanced infrastructure.
From Taroko Gorge to Alishan forests, the island offers striking landscapes.
Regular earthquakes and typhoons pose significant risk.
Trailheads are reachable by public transit, making weekend hikes easy.
Live houses, KTV, and festivals provide diverse evening entertainment.
Night markets and late eateries create a social yet family-friendly nightlife.
Groups like Taipei IGDA and local forums connect developers.
Studios such as Rayark and Red Candle show local creativity.
Innovation grants and the Taiwan Gold Card support entrepreneurial founders.
Taipei moves fast, while smaller cities like Tainan offer a slower rhythm.
School-centric culture pressures parents toward after-school tutoring.
Requires over five years' residence, language tests, and renouncing prior citizenship.
Transparency International ranks Taiwan relatively clean with strong anti-graft agencies.
Multi-party democratic republic with regular competitive elections.
Polyamorous relationships lack legal recognition and remain largely taboo.
Public preschools are expanding but urban waitlists are common.
Private and international schools exist but command high tuition.
Digital democracy initiatives and LGBTQ rights reflect a broadly progressive society.
Government messaging focuses on civic campaigns rather than ideology.
Free press and vibrant media limit state-controlled narratives.
Taipei MRT and intercity rail are clean, reliable, and extensive.
Religion rarely influences policy, keeping governance largely secular.
Co-working spaces support remote work, though many employers prefer office presence.
Work visas, spousal ARCs, and three-year Gold Cards provide varied stay options.
State pension offers modest payouts, supplemented by private savings.
Foreigners may retire but receive limited pension benefits unless contributing long-term.
Ruby on Rails is used in some startups and fintech but isn't mainstream.
Taiwan ranks among the world's safest countries with very low violent crime.
Bilingual programs and international schools give alternatives to standard Mandarin instruction.
Coastal waters range roughly 22°C in winter to 29°C in summer (72–84°F).
Subtropical climate means hot, humid summers and mild winters with frequent rain.
Public discussions of sexuality remain conservative despite some urban liberalization.
Progressive on healthcare and LGBTQ rights but conservative on drugs and conscription.
Spring sees 18–26°C (64–79°F) with blossoms and occasional rain.
Domestic stability is high though cross-strait tensions persist.
Emphasis on democratic values and a market economy rather than a single ideology.
Entrepreneurial environment with strong private sector and venture support.

Public confidence rose after effective pandemic response and open data efforts.
Issues mainly involve petty bribery or influence peddling and are generally prosecuted.

Labor laws guarantee 7–15 paid days depending on tenure.
Most employees take around two weeks off annually, matching legal minimums.
Public sentiment is warm toward Japan but wary of China's intentions.

values.key: View of Them by Neighboring Countries
values.alignmentText: Japan and the U.S. view Taiwan favorably, while China claims it as territory.
Strong national identity centers on democracy and resilience.
Work visas, family reunification, entrepreneur visas, and the flexible Gold Card offer multiple routes.
Close ties with the U.S. and friendly locals make Americans generally well received.
Blend of high-tech industry and vibrant traditional culture stands out.
Winters hover around 13–18°C (55–65°F) in Taipei with cool rain.
Legal cap is 40 hours, yet overtime is common in practice.
Long hours and after-work obligations can strain family time.
Labor laws mandate overtime pay and leave, but enforcement varies in smaller firms.
